Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CBSA officer's decision under subsection 72(1) of IRPA
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence (affidavit, letter, documents) deemed insufficient to establish Jewish identity or personalized risk
Decision_Outcome: No personalized risk found; PRRA application denied
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate new information and personal risk
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's credibility previously rejected in 2002 asylum claim
Legal_Rule: PRRA must consider new evidence not available during original claim; prior findings respected unless contradicted
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged anti-Semitic risks in Ukraine due to Jewish identity
Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed; no violation of procedural fairness or substantive rights found
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Officer properly considered submissions and applied correct legal framework
Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavit, letter, supporting documents regarding Jewish identity and conditions in Ukraine
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged CBSA officerâ€™s negative PRRA decision
Legal_Rule_Source: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Defendant_Response: CBSA maintained decision was reasonable and based on insufficient new evidence
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of CBSA decision and remittal for re-assessment
Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to overturn PRRA refusal
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Persecution based on religion (Jewish identity) in Ukraine
Governing_Rule: PRRA decisions must be reasonable and consider new evidence
